title-group.article-title: Commonly Used “Nutrition” Indicators Do Not Predict Outcome in the Critically Ill
title-group.subtitle: A Systematic Review

author-notes.corresp: Suzie Ferrie, Department of Nutrition & Dietetics, Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Missenden Road, Camperdown NSW 2050, Australia. Email: suzie.ferrie@sswahs.nsw.gov.au

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2013 American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition
permissions.copyright-holder: The American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

abstract.p: Background: In everyday practice, clinicians use a variety of anthropometric, biochemical, and clinical indicators to monitor nutrition therapy, but these have limitations in the critically ill. This systematic review of randomized controlled trials aimed to assess whether commonly used anthropometric, biochemical, and clinical nutrition indicators are predictive of patient outcomes in the critically ill. Materials and Methods: A computerized bibliographic search was performed using MEDLINE, EMBASE, and CINAHL from 1950 to December 2012, as well as a citation review of relevant articles. Randomized clinical trials of any nutrition interventions in critically ill patients were included if they reported any nutrition indicator after baseline and any clinically meaningful outcome variables. Information about study quality, setting, and findings was extracted using standardized protocols. Because of the heterogeneity of study characteristics, only a narrative synthesis was undertaken. Results: Of 223 studies obtained with the search strategy, 2 independent reviewers identified selected 51 studies meeting the eligibility criteria. These reported indicators such as serum albumin, serum prealbumin (transthyretin), retinol-binding protein, transferrin, and lymphocytes. Thirty studies did not report a significant difference in clinical outcomes. Of the remainder, the number of studies supporting a statistical relationship between outcome and particular nutrition indicators was equal to, or outnumbered by, the studies not supporting such a relationship. Conclusion: None of the commonly used nutrition monitoring parameters demonstrated consistent associations with outcome in randomized controlled trials. Development of nutrition indicators other than laboratory tests that are more closely linked to the patient’s clinical progress should be a priority.

body.p: Assessment of nutrition status in the critically ill continues to be discussed in the literature.1,2 Once a patient’s admission in the intensive care unit (ICU) extends beyond a few days, however, nutrition monitoring becomes important, and this issue has not received as much attention in the critically ill. Many well-documented nutrition assessment parameters (such as Subjective Global Assessment classification3-6 or serum albumin level7) are excellent prognostic indicators, predicting mortality, morbidity, and length of hospital stay in patients both in and outside the ICU. But these indicators do not change significantly within the timeframe of a short-term response to nutrition therapy, so they are not useful for assessing whether the nutrition provided is optimal. There is a need for indicators of nutrition progress that can be monitored sequentially, where the change in the indicator over time is predictive of an improved outcome.

Monitoring response to nutrition support in the ICU is important because, although it is recognized that nutrition improves outcomes in the critically ill,8,9 the nutrition requirements of critically ill patients remain unclear and in some areas controversial. For example, even when an accurate evaluation of energy expenditure is possible, opinions differ as to whether it is appropriate to attempt to match this value or to aim for a lower target for nutrition support.10,11 In addition, recommendations for the protein and micronutrient requirements of the critically ill are not based on high-level evidence. Nutrition monitoring would ideally provide an early indication as to whether an individual patient’s needs are being met optimally, allowing adjustments to be made promptly (rather than waiting for clinical complications such as poor wound healing to indicate that a change is needed).

Many commonly used strategies for monitoring nutrition progress are not easily applicable in the ICU setting. Body weight and anthropometric measures may be altered by short-term body fluid changes; biochemical indices are often deranged in severe illness or trauma; methods that rely on the patient’s response may not be possible due to reduced level of consciousness, neuromuscular blockade, or sedation. Despite this, a recent survey12 indicated that many ICU dietitians continue to rely on parameters such as body weight and serum albumin in their nutrition monitoring of the critically ill; other commonly used “nutrition” indicators include serum prealbumin (transthyretin), nitrogen balance, transferrin, lymphocyte counts or ratios, and C-reactive protein.12 It is unclear whether there is any association between patients’ clinical outcome and an improvement in any of these nutrition indicators, and it appears that this has not been studied in any well-controlled trials previously. Existing high-quality studies in an ICU population, however, may yield data that elucidates this question.

This study aims to use a systematic review methodology to address the following research question: do any of the commonly used nutrition parameters predict clinically meaningful outcomes in the critically ill?

sec.title: Search Strategy
sec.p: A search for relevant publications was conducted using MEDLINE, EMBASE, and CINAHL from the earliest date available in each database and without any limitation on language of publication. Date of the last search was December 3, 2012. Additional articles were located from the reference lists of relevant articles. See Table 1 for terms used in the search.

tr.td: nutrition$.ti OR nutrition$.ab) AND (ICU OR ITU OR critical illness OR critically ill OR critical care OR intensive care OR intensive care units OR sepsis OR bacteremia
nutrition$ assessment OR nutrition$ screening OR nutrition$ risk OR nutrition$ status
outcome$ OR mortality OR stay OR predict$ OR morbidity OR LOS OR wound OR indicat$ OR infectio$ OR complicat$

fn.p: .ti, title; .ab, abstract; .lim, limit. $ used to indicate truncation.

sec.title: Selection and Data Extraction
sec.p: All potentially relevant studies had their titles and abstracts screened for eligibility by 2 researchers independently, using the following criteria: (1) the study had a major focus on nutrition, (2) the study targeted an adult critically ill population, and (3) the study reported on nutrition status or nutrition monitoring. Articles were retrieved if they appeared to be potentially eligible, and 2 researchers then independently examined the full text of each article and then came to consensus on the selection of the articles based on the eligibility criteria. Any disagreements were resolved by discussion. The eligibility criteria were as follows:

list-item.p: Study population was an adult ICU population as defined by Doig et al.13
Study reported at least one of the “nutrition” indicators in use by ICU dietitians12 at more than 1 time point during the study (ie, baseline and any later time point).
Study reported on clinically significant outcomes, that is, some measure of how the patient feels, functions, or survives (such as mortality, length of stay, infectious complications).

sec.p: Studies were excluded from the review if they were not randomized, focused on a non–critically ill population, included children, or did not report clinically meaningful outcomes or currently used “nutrition” indicators. See Figure 1 for details of this process of article selection.

caption.p: Study selection process. ICU, intensive care unit; RCT, randomized controlled trial.

sec.title: Data Synthesis
sec.p: Each study was reviewed to assess whether changes in the nutrition indicators in the separate arms of the study were related to the outcomes of the study. Since lack of a significant relationship between nutrition indicator and outcome may be a consequence of the failure of the intervention (rather than a failure of the indicator), the focus of this review was on studies in which a significant difference in outcome was demonstrated.

Due to the heterogeneity in study design and outcomes reported by the studies, undertaking a meta-analysis was not appropriate. A narrative analysis was performed, describing the study design, study population, intervention, and the relation between any “nutrition” indicators reported and outcomes of interest. In extracting the data, study quality was assessed by both researchers independently. Quality was assessed on the basis of previously published criteria as described by Doig et al,13 Graf et al,14 and Heyland et al.15 These identify the limitations of each study using the following questions: Were the selection criteria, randomization and blinding methods, treatment protocols, outcomes, and any cointerventions described clearly and objectively defined with sufficient detail? Were groups comparable at baseline? Was intent-to-treat analysis performed? Was follow-up complete? Each study was scored by the researchers independently, and the results of higher and lower quality studies were compared.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Using the search process described above, 223 studies remained once duplicates were removed. Of these, 51 studies were found that met the inclusion criteria, that is, they were randomized trials in an ICU population that reported on both outcomes and nutrition indicators. None was published before 1992. All of the studies are listed in Table 2.16-66 Of these, 30 did not show any significant difference in clinical outcome between the control and intervention groups. As the aim was to find parameters that predict improved outcomes, these studies were not examined further.

tr.th: Studies With Significant Improvement in Both Outcomes and Nutrition Indicators

fn.p: BCAA, branched-chain amino acids; COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; CRP, C-reactive protein; EN, enteral nutrition; EPA, eicosapentaenoic acid; GI, gastrointestinal; GLA, γ-linolenic acid; ICU, intensive care unit; IGF-1, insulin-like growth factor 1; IL-6, interleukin-6; IV, intravenous; LCT, long-chain triglyceride; LOS, length of stay; MCT, medium-chain triglyceride; NS, no significant difference between intervention and control groups; PINI, Prognostic Inflammatory and Nutritional Index; PN, parenteral nutrition; PNI, Prognostic Nutritional Index; SIRS, systemic inflammatory response syndrome; WC, white cell; WCC, total white cell count.

sec.p: The remaining 21 studies all reported significant improvements in clinical outcome. In 9 of these studies, these outcome improvements were not reflected by changes in any of the nutrition parameters that were measured. In the other 12 studies, a variety of nutrition parameters was reported, which variously did or did not reflect the outcome improvements. See Table 3 for details of these nutrition parameters. Note that there is considerable overlap between these 2 groups of parameters—that is, many of the parameters were predictive of outcome in one study but not in another. In an attempt to resolve this contradiction, the quality of each study was assessed in case quality weighting might alter the interpretation of the results. Six studies16,17,22,26,30,35 were rated “true high quality” by the criteria of Doig et al,13 but a similar overlap was seen even within these 6 studies’ results. When a median split was used to divide between higher quality and lower quality studies, there was no significant difference in terms of obtaining a significant result (P = .41). On that basis, it was decided that all of the studies would be included in the review, irrespective of quality score.

caption.p: Relationship Between Outcomes and Nutrition Parameters, in Studies With Significantly Improved Outcome.

tr.th: Nutrition Parameters Measured in the Reviewed RCTs

tr.td: Body weight at ICU day 7 or 14 or discharge
Body weight at ICU day 5, 10a, 12, 14, or 15

fn.p: ICU, intensive care unit; IGF-1, insulin-like growth factor 1; IL-6, interleukin-6; PINI, Prognostic Inflammatory and Nutritional Index; RCT, randomized controlled trial; WCC, total white cell count.

sec.p: The results of this process are described in detail below for nutrition parameters that were reported in 3 or more studies and for the parameters reported as commonly used by ICU dietitians.12

sec.title: Weight
sec.p: Three higher quality studies33-35 and 1 lower quality study20 identified in this search found no relationship between outcome and weight measured variously on ICU days 5, 10, 12, 14, and 15. Four lower quality studies19,21,25,27 found that weight on ICU day 7 or 14 was predictive of better outcome. In 3 of these studies, the difference in body weight between the intervention and control groups was 1–2 kg.

sec.title: Nitrogen Balance
sec.p: Improved nitrogen balance was associated with better outcome in 2 higher quality studies22,23 and 1 lower quality study.24 In these studies, it was measured on ICU day 4 (in 1 study) and ICU day 7 (in all 3 studies). The difference between groups ranged from 2–10 g/d of nitrogen. No such association was seen in 2 higher quality studies30,31 and 3 lower quality studies,18,28,32 in which it was measured variously on days 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 10, and 11 of the ICU stay.

sec.title: Serum Albumin
sec.p: Of the 10 higher quality studies, 8 measured serum albumin levels, and only 2 studies17,22 found any association between improved serum albumin level (on ICU day 3, 5, 7, or 10) and improved clinical outcome. Of the 10 lower quality studies, 6 measured serum albumin (on day 3, 7, or 14), and 2 of these19,21 found an association with improved outcome. Overall, 10 studies16,20,23,25,31-36 found no association between outcome and serum albumin level measured variously on day 5, 7, 10, 12, 14, 15, or 21 of the ICU stay. All of these reported a difference of 4–7 g/L in serum albumin level between the control and intervention groups.

sec.title: Serum Prealbumin (Transthyretin)
sec.p: Seven of the 10 higher quality studies measured serum prealbumin, and 4 of these16,22,23,26 found an association between improved outcome and higher serum prealbumin levels when measured on ICU day 3, 5, 7, or 14. Four of the 10 lower quality studies measured serum prealbumin, and 2 of these18,27 found a similar association when serum prealbumin was measured on ICU day 3, 7, or 11. Five studies did not find any such association.30,32-36 Of the 6 studies that did find serum prealbumin level to be predictive of outcome, only 2 reported differences in serum prealbumin >0.02 g/L between the intervention and control groups.18,26 In 2 other studies, although the difference between groups was statistically significant, all of the reported serum prealbumin levels were within the normal range for both groups.22,23

sec.title: Retinol-Binding Protein
sec.p: In 2 lower quality studies18,32 and 1 higher quality study,30 no association was seen between outcome and retinol-binding protein (RBP) measured on ICU day 5 or 10. In 1 higher quality study,16 RBP on ICU day 7 was predictive of improved outcome, but despite a statistically significant difference between groups, all of the reported RBP levels were within the normal range.

sec.title: Transferrin
sec.p: Two higher quality studies22,26 and 1 lower quality study27 found an association between outcome and transferrin measured on ICU day 3, 5, 7, or 10. In 1 of the higher quality studies, all of the reported transferrin levels were within the normal range in both the intervention and control groups; in the other, the difference in transferrin level was 0.5 g/L. The lower quality study reported only the direction of the relationship without specifying the actual transferrin levels. Four higher quality studies16,33-35 and 2 lower quality studies20,32 found no relationship between transferrin level and outcome.

sec.title: Lymphocytes
sec.p: One higher quality study17 found that lymphocyte count on ICU day 10 was predictive of outcome, although all the reported levels were within the normal range for both groups in the study. Four higher quality studies23,33-35 and 2 lower quality studies20,21 found no association between outcome and lymphocyte count.

sec.title: C-Reactive Protein
sec.p: Three higher quality studies17,23,26 found that lower C-reactive protein levels (on ICU day 7, 10, or 14) were predictive of improved outcome. In all of these, there was an approximately 2-fold difference between groups. One higher quality study16 and 2 lower quality studies25,32 did not find any association between C-reactive protein and outcome.

sec.title: CD4/CD8 Ratio
sec.p: Two lower quality studies20,27 found an association between outcome and CD4/CD8 ratio measured on day 7 or 15 of ICU stay. One lower quality study28 found no such relationship.

sec.title: Other Commonly Used Parameters
sec.p: Only 1 identified (lower quality) study21 used grip strength as a measure, finding a 2-kg difference in grip strength between groups that was associated with better outcome when measured on days 3 and 7 of the ICU stay (but not when measured at hospital discharge). Increased total serum protein was found to be predictive of outcome in 1 higher quality study,17 but this relationship was not seen in 1 other higher quality study.31

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This review was conducted to summarize evidence on the relationship between patient outcomes and commonly used nutrition parameters. A rigorous systematic review methodology was used, with studies restricted to those with a randomized design, to minimize the effect of the many potential confounders that have made observational studies on this topic difficult to interpret. For example, many cohort studies do not take into account differing severity of illness or inflammation. One such study compared patients on enteral, parenteral, and dual nutrition in ICU with respect to anthropometric and biochemical indicators and found that serum prealbumin increased only in the dual-nutrition group after 14 days of nutrition support, but patients receiving the different forms of nutrition were not comparable at baseline and had very different distributions of diagnoses.67 A study in head-injured patients found that serum prealbumin, RBP, and nitrogen balance were better in the enterally fed patients compared with those receiving parenteral nutrition, even though they all received the same amounts of energy and protein.68 A prospective cohort study comparing nutrition intake with weight, serum albumin, serum prealbumin, body composition, and lymphocytes in ICU patients found no correlation,69 whereas another70 found significant improvements in serum prealbumin, transferrin, and RBP with nutrition support in a variety of surgical and nonsurgical patients. The results appear to be mixed, and there are no published systematic reviews of ICU cohort or observational studies on this topic.

There were significant inconsistencies in the results of this review, and it is not possible to draw any strong conclusions. There are several reasons why this might be the case. First, although the studies were of nutrition therapy interventions, in many cases, the improved outcomes could have been due to a mechanism other than a direct nutrition one and thus not be associated with any noticeable change in nutrition indicators.

Second, although the studies encompass a wide range of ICU patients and conditions, it should be noted that none of the studies examined in this review were designed to address the clinical question being investigated here. All were randomized controlled trials of some intervention designed to improve outcomes, with nutrition indicators being only a peripheral aspect of the study, measured infrequently and often incompletely reported. This means that even the high-quality studies examined were not an ideal way to assess the relationship between outcomes and nutrition indicators.

Third, the number of included studies was reduced because studies that do not show an improved outcome were not analyzed, since the aim was to find nutrition indicators that predict an improvement in outcome. Studies in which there was no improvement in outcome are unhelpful in this aim and could not be analyzed as there is no way to distinguish between studies in which the indicator correctly predicted a lack of outcome improvement (due to an ineffective intervention) vs studies in which there was a type II error.

However, despite these limitations, the results do raise grave concerns about how meaningful these commonly used nutrition parameters could be in clinical practice, given that they appear to have no consistent association with patient outcomes. Looking at the number and quality of studies supporting (or not supporting) a relationship between outcome and any individual parameter, it is possible to rank the commonly used parameters. In descending order of support from the literature examined, the order is as follows: serum prealbumin, nitrogen balance, RBP, total serum protein, body weight, transferrin, lymphocyte count, and serum albumin level. In the case of serum prealbumin, 5 of the 11 studies reporting a serum prealbumin level found no relationship with outcome. Six of the 11 found the serum prealbumin level to be predictive of outcome, but only 2 of these 6 studies reported a clinically significant difference in serum prealbumin level that would be identifiable in everyday practice. For all of the other commonly used indicators, the number of supportive studies was outnumbered by those that found no relationship with outcome, and a number of the supportive studies reported clinically undetectable differences.

The traditional use of these nutrition parameters has largely been based on their “validation” in studies that are neither randomized nor controlled, and in many cases, they are misapplied if used for short-term monitoring in a critical care setting. For example, the literature on serum albumin includes a large meta-analysis of 90 prospective and retrospective cohort studies (total nearly 300,000 subjects) that found serum albumin level to be a strong independent predictor of poor outcome, associated with mortality, morbidity, ICU length of stay (LOS), hospital LOS, and hospital cost in a dose-dependent fashion.71 This would appear to support the role of serum albumin as a useful indicator of the patient’s progress in the hospital, since it correlates so strongly with meaningful differences in outcome. However, the majority of the 90 studies in the meta-analysis were reporting on the mortality predictive power of a single serum albumin level, mostly measured at study entry or admission or within the first few days of admission, or prior to surgery or other planned treatment. That is, these studies were not designed to investigate the use of sequential serum albumin levels as a parameter for monitoring nutrition progress, and therefore the meta-analysis does not constitute support for this practice. In addition, it is not clear whether attempts to manipulate the serum albumin level would have any effect on outcome. The same meta-analysis also looked at the effect of increasing the serum albumin level with the use of intravenous albumin infusion and found that the resulting improved serum level does not equate to an improved outcome. Spontaneous changes in serum albumin occur only slowly and are strongly affected by the acute phase response and compartmental fluid shifts,72 so improvements in serum albumin level may not be obvious in the first few weeks of critical illness even with optimal nutrition support.73 It therefore appears that, although serum albumin has excellent prognostic value when measured before treatment, it is not valid as an indicator of nutrition progress in the short term.

Similarly, total lymphocyte count has a long history as part of nutrition assessment, based on its strong prognostic value. The lymphocyte count decreases as part of the immunologic dysfunction that occurs with malnutrition.74 This results in an increase in the frequency and severity of infection and consequent poorer outcomes. A 4-fold increase in mortality was reported with a total lymphocyte count below normal,75 and lymphocyte count has been incorporated into a number of screening tools.76-78 In a critically ill population, however, a reduced lymphocyte count does not have adequate specificity to be useful,69,79-80 and there is no evidence to support the use of sequential lymphocyte counts in monitoring a patient’s response to nutrition support.

Body weight is the most commonly used indicator in assessing nutrition status in everyday life, but the confounding effects of fluid retention in critical illness, and its gradual loss in the first few ICU weeks,81 mean that short-term changes in weight will indicate fluid balance rather than nutrition response in this setting. Weight may thus be a valuable parameter to monitor in the ICU, but not for nutrition reasons. Although resolving fluid retention may correlate with improved outcomes, this may be mediated by factors other than nutrition ones and not correlate with nutrition adequacy in a way that allows it to be used as a nutrition monitoring parameter.

Nitrogen balance is widely used for estimating patients’ protein losses, which can help to establish protein requirements, but loss of protein does not appear to correlate clearly with function in critical illness.82,83 This may explain why nitrogen balance does not consistently predict outcome, limiting its use as a nutrition indicator early in the ICU stay.

Transferrin, too, appears to be unreliable for this purpose, perhaps because of the confounding effect of iron status and inflammatory changes on transferrin level,84 giving inconsistent results when attempting to correlate it with outcome. In this review, only 3 of 9 studies supported such a relationship, and 2 of these 3 reported differences that are smaller than a laboratory’s range of error.

Serum prealbumin level is one of the more widely used parameters examined in this review. It has been popular as a nutrition marker because its short half-life means that significant changes are seen within days or weeks.84 It has been claimed that this reflects nutrition input,85 but this has not been consistently supported in the literature. For example, serum prealbumin levels did not decrease when protein intake was decreased below the recommended minimum level in healthy volunteers,86 nor did they correlate with the extent of chronic weight loss in healthy volunteers87 or in patients with eating disorders.88 Studies suggesting that serum prealbumin level reflects nutrition rehabilitation are confounded by unrandomized design and the possible influence of inflammation.89-92 A recent retrospective study in mostly critically ill patients found that serum prealbumin correated with inflammatory markers rather than with nutrition delivery.93 Concerns about this have been raised elsewhere94,95 and are substantiated by the findings of this review of randomized studies, in which serum prealbumin did not consistently predict outcome and where even the supportive studies mostly reported clinically insignificant changes.

During a long ICU admission, patients often display marked catabolism, and this cannot be totally prevented by increasing nutrition support.81,96,97 The extent of catabolism may possibly be reduced with optimized nutrition, however. Currently, there is no validated way to measure nutrition response on a day-to-day basis, so it is not possible to feel confident that the current nutrition regimen is optimal or to assuage doubts about its adequacy when there is a poor clinical outcome later on. A short-term parameter that could reliably monitor response to nutrition in the critically ill, within the same timeframe as the nutrition therapy, would therefore be very valuable in clinical practice. Laboratory tests are particularly attractive in the intensive care setting as they are easily used in an unconscious patient, unlike many of the functional measures used outside the ICU such as grip strength. It may be the case that there will never be a “magic number” for assessing nutrition progress, and instead further work is needed to formalize the measurement of clinical outcomes such as ventilatory weaning, wound healing, and return of physical functioning, which are more meaningful to the individual patient.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: It appears that although outcomes in ICU can be improved in studies of various nutrition interventions, no commonly used anthropometric or biochemical indicator consistently predicts this. This suggests that assessing nutrition progress by monitoring such parameters, or aiming to achieve improvements in them by nutrition strategies, is not clinically meaningful.
